headline: How to Make the Best Cauliflower Pizza Crust
description: Yes, you really can make pizza out of cauliflower! This cauliflower crust is gluten-free, not hard at all to execute, and tastes great because you've made it yourself. Top it with any of your favorite pizza toppings and grab a slice!
name: How to Make the Best Cauliflower Pizza Crust
recipeIngredient: 2 cups cauliflower florets (7 ounces), cut into 1/2-inch pieces
1/2 cup corn flour (or masa harina) (57 g)
1/2 cup tomato sauce, homemade or store-bought
4 ounces fresh or shredded mozzarella cheese
Sliced tomatoes, basil, pepperoni, ham, pineapple, mushrooms, and/or olives (enough to lightly coat the cheese)

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 475°F: Place the oven rack in the upper-middle position.

Process the dough: Add cauliflower florets, corn flour, egg, olive oil, and salt to a food processor. Process on high speed, scraping down the bowl every 30 seconds, until a smooth and sticky puree if formed—about 3 minutes total. Add the cornstarch and process on high speed for 30 seconds. Add Parmesan cheese and pulse until just combined, 5 to 6 pulses.

Shape the crust: Lightly grease a piece of parchment paper with olive oil. Transfer pizza dough to the paper. Lightly sprinkle more corn flour on top. Use your hands to press and shape the dough into a 10-inch circle, then use a rolling pin to gently roll out the dough to about 11-inch circle. Dust the dough with more corn flour as needed to prevent sticking while shaping and rolling.

Par-bake the crust: Bake the crust for 10 minutes. Remove the crust from the oven and allow it to cool for 3 minutes, and then run a spatula underneath the crust to carefully remove and then transfer to a wire rack set inside a baking sheet. Discard the parchment.
Add toppings: Spread the pizza sauce over the crust, leaving a 1/2-inch border. Place the cheese and tomatoes (or other toppings) on top.
Bake the pizza: Bake until the cheese is melted and pizza edges are golden and lightly crisp, 5 to 7 minutes.

Serve: Garnish pizza with fresh basil leaves, sprinkle with salt and black pepper. Leftovers will keep for about a week. To reheat, place on a foil-lined baking sheet and cook at 375°F until the cheese is melted and the crust is warm and crisp, 5 to 7 minutes.

review.reviewBody: This cauliflower pizza crust recipe exceeded my expectations. We topped it with a jarred tomato sauce, bell pepper, mushrooms and a few sun-dried tomatoes. I found the dough to be difficult to roll out even after adding more and more corn flour so my husband stepped in and spread it by hand into a pizza pan. It was so delicious that we devoured the whole thing in one sitting.

SO good !! I topped with diced tomatoes, strips of canadian bacon, pineapples, black olives, onions & shredded cheese. Also, added oregano, basil, garlic & onion powders to crust..... and a little more oregano, basil and snips of rosemary to diced tomatoes....AMAZING !

An amazing recipe , crispy on the edges and yummy chewy topping, I add a sprinkle of mix herbs on top of the mozzarella, I'll definitely make this again. 
Thanks for sharing your delicious recipe.

I just made this and it far exceeded my expectations for the floppy, soggy looking cauliflower crust I keep seeing around the internet. 
I substituted about 3/4 cup chickpea flour (plus more for dusting) for the masa. I got a pretty wet and sticky dough, but I just took my time shaping/rolling it out carefully to get it even and it cooked and dried out beautifully. Tearable and foldable texture. We are just doing carb avoidance, so gluten is not a factor, but this is gluten free and much more nutritious with the chickpea flour, and easier to do than a regular pizza dough. Sometimes you just need that pizza fix! thanks!
I need a no carb version, too!
